name.description: Hank Danos was born about 1950 in Larose, La., and grew up there and in Cut Off, La. He has lived in Lafourche Parish for all his life but the years he attended Louisiana State University, where he earned a B.S. in Business Administration (1971). He is the CEO and President of Danos, which was founded by his father (as Danos and Curole Marine Contractors); Hank joined in 1971. Danos is a member of the LSU Board of Supervisors and a number of other state and national boards. He continues to serve as the head of Danos, which he now runs with his sons. He is a practicing Catholic and served in the National Guard.

subject.topic: Oil field equipment and supplies industry--Louisiana.

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)

mods.abstract: Danos discusses his childhood in Larose and Cut Off, La., including his grandfather's sugar cane farm and the slightly more populated neighborhood in Cut Off. Danos recalls transportation options and the physical construction of the community, and how it was changed. Danos says living in Bayou Lafourche is defined by pride of culture and independence. He discusses the oil industry's growth, role, and his contributions through Danos and Curole. He discusses hurricanes, his current approach to them, and the role the floodgates have had on the local community. He describes his maternal grandfather's house, as well as the house his parents built in Cut Off. He also recalls food options on the bayou (groceries and restaurants), then and now.
